AWS IOT was introduced about two and a half years ago as our core service to be
in a lot of ways the front door for devices to access all of AWS AWS IOT is
made up of a few core elements and includes pub/sub messaging service and a
protocol broker for ingesting data from devices it includes a security model based on certificate mutual
authentication between devices and the cloud to ensure that you have AWS level rock-solid security it includes a rules
engine that helps you route this data to the applications that need to use it and some developer features including the
device Shadow which is a digital representation of that device in the cloud which is really key because it's a
fundamental developer feature when you can describe a device as a set of API is it unlocks a lot of potential for
developers to build those companion apps those web dashboards and other applications that are always a part of
any IOT solution as part of routing that data to where it needs to be the third
the third and final bucket is the intelligence that you need to bring on top of that raw data that you're

help you solve a business problem and driving a level of intelligence from that data is actually the end goal and
so AWS has its own analytics platform AI
platform database tools application development tools and so forth but we
also count many third-party solutions like the work we've done with Salesforce is a really core part of building that
Intelligence layer on top of that connection to the devices and that orchestration that the cloud brings
now AWS IOT does a few things for you it helps you securely connect devices to WS
and other devices at scale it helps you enable applications to interact with devices even when they're offline helps

rest of AWS it's that front door to the rest of AWS it really allows you to build the full end-to-end set of
solutions that you would need now the cloud is great we definitely believe in
that but there is also a value of processing data closer to the source
we've discovered this with a lot of work with customers and I think across the
industry this is pretty well known that there are a lot of times particularly as you're building IOT solutions that being
closer to the source of data is important and there's three main reasons for that that we've discovered the first
reason is all-around physics it's about latency it's about the fact that despite everyone's best efforts we
really can't change the speed of light and the best connection in the world sometimes can be too slow you think
about real time systems and safety systems in a manufacturing environment
or to say seat safety systems on the device it can simply be too slow even
with the best connections to the Internet you need to be closer to get that really low latency it's also a
matter of physics that no amount of code can fix a broken connection so if you don't have connectivity you can't code
your way out of that problem you need to be closer to the source and perhaps bring some of that intelligence closer
to the device the second big reason is about economics so I'd like to talk
about the fact that data has weight and in a lot of these applications you generate massive amounts of data that
can either be impractical or expensive to move from the source I think about
autonomous driving as an example or many manufacturing scenarios where you'll be
generating megabytes terabytes of data you may want to do something with that data filter and reduce that data locally
at the source before moving it to the cloud for a lot of economic reasons and the last is compliance
they're just laws about what you can and can't do privacy did its sovereignty and so for its limit and you may have to be
closer to the data for all of those reasons so because of that we had a lot
of feedback from customers hey we love the technology that you've built into the cloud to help us enable IOT
solutions but we need to move that closer to the edge and so last year we introduced and earlier this year brought
into general availability a service called AWS green grass green grass is essentially an extension of AWS out to
the edge it is software that runs on your devices and brings to that device a
couple of core capabilities first it brings the same fundamental IOT
technologies that we have in AWS IOT and runs them locally on that device that
means you get the same security model the same message broker the same rules engine and the same device shadow and
registry that you do in the clouds second it brings lambda our server lists
compute platform to the device that allows you to write code and run that code on any device Greengrass is
available on and it really enables an embedded developer to take advantage of
some of the modern application development techniques from the cloud and it brings that out to the edge and
brings it to the embedded developer it also allows you to use that same technology the lambdas that you would
use in AWS IOT to respond to events you have that same model out on the device
all of this is made available like I said a software that runs on your devices and Greengrass can arbitrate
whether compute takes place on the device in the cloud or a little bit of
both and also handles the case where you might have a loss of connectivity or no connectivity at all and all of that is
within the developers control there's a lot of benefits to doing this I've

very quickly it helps you operate offline whether that offline situation

lets you have this local runtime in the form of lamda which is incredibly
